other.leaveContentBodyValidate: If you want to save the changes, you must first validate the form
other.aiMentorInstructionsTooltip: Describe how the AI Mentor should behave during the lesson. Include the context, role, or scenario that the AI should follow. This defines how the AI will guide the conversation.
other.completionConditionsTooltip: List what the student must achieve to pass this lesson. Provide clear and measurable points. The AI will use this list to check progress. You can also define a pass threshold (e.g. percentage or minimum number of points to cover). If no threshold is provided, all conditions must be met to pass the lesson.
other.passThresholdTooltip: Set the minimum percentage (1-100%) required to pass. Leave empty for no threshold.
other.overwriteContentDescription: This will replace your current content with the selected example. Are you sure you want to continue?

instructions.scenarioSimulation: You play the role of a business client who is looking for a supplier of software development services. You have specific requirements: the app must be ready within 3 months, you have a limited budget, and you expect clear communication. The student plays the role of the sales representative who wants to win your business. The AI Mentor should respond as the client, asking questions and expressing concerns.
instructions.problemSolving: You play the role of an employee who requests a salary increase. You believe you deserve it because of your recent contributions. However, the company currently has no available budget for raises. The student plays the manager who needs to handle the conversation constructively, showing empathy and trying to find an alternative solution.
instructions.creativeTask: You ask the student to propose an idea for a new service that the company could offer to its customers. Your role is to encourage creativity, ask follow-up questions, and help the student refine their concept.
instructions.knowledgeSharing: You play the role of an experienced mentor who shares knowledge about time management techniques. The conversation is informal: you introduce concepts, give examples, and encourage the student to reflect. Occasionally you ask light, open-ended questions to check understanding. The goal is to guide, not to test.

conditions.scenarioSimulation:
• The student asks about the client's budget.
  • The student asks about the timeline.
  • The student uses SPIN selling or another sales technique.
  • The student identifies the client's key pain points.
  • The student offers a proposal that matches the client's constraints.
Threshold: at least 3 out of 5 conditions must be met.
conditions.problemSolving:
• The student acknowledges the employee's contribution.
  • The student explains the budget situation honestly.
  • The student proposes a non-financial alternative (e.g. additional benefits, development opportunity).
  • The student agrees to revisit the topic at a later date.
  • The student maintains a respectful, supportive tone.
Threshold: at least 3 out of 5 conditions must be met.
conditions.creativeTask:
• The student presents an original idea.
  • The student explains who the target audience is.
  • The student describes how the service could provide value to customers.
  • The student identifies potential challenges.
(No threshold defined — all conditions must be met.)
conditions.knowledgeSharing:
• The student engages actively in the conversation (asks questions or shares reflections).
  • The student can name at least one time management technique mentioned in the dialogue.
  • The student expresses how they might apply one technique in their work.
(No threshold defined — all conditions recommended, but not mandatory for passing.)
